statement.text: A mycotic (infected) aortic aneurysm is a localized, infected outpouching of the aortic wall resulting from bacterial seeding of atherosclerotic plaque, adjacent infected tissue, septic emboli, or direct trauma. Despite the name, most are bacterial (not fungal) in origin, with Salmonella and Staphylococcus being most common.
statement.formal: Mycotic Aneurysm: Infected arterial dilation from bacterial seeding. Common organisms: Salmonella spp. (especially elderly), Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus spp.

explanation.intuition: Think of a mycotic aneurysm as an abscess that forms in the wall of a major blood vessel. Bacteria land on a vulnerable area (usually a diseased plaque) and start to digest the arterial wall, causing it to weaken and balloon outward rapidly. This is a surgical emergency because the infected, weakened wall has a very high risk of rupture.
explanation.key_insight: The term 'mycotic' is a misnomer coined by Osler in 1885 because the aneurysms resembled fungal vegetations. The vast majority are actually caused by bacteria, not fungi. Salmonella has a particular tropism for atherosclerotic aorta in elderly patients.
explanation.technical_details: Mycotic aneurysms are saccular, eccentric, and rapidly enlarging. They occur in atypical locations for degenerative aneurysms (e.g., suprarenal, pararenal aorta). Blood cultures are positive in 50-75%. CT findings include periaortic gas, fluid, soft tissue stranding, and saccular morphology. Treatment requires both surgical repair and prolonged (often lifelong) antibiotic therapy.
common_misconceptions: Mycotic means fungal - most are bacterial
All infected aneurysms are mycotic - graft infection is a distinct entity
EVAR is contraindicated - may be used as bridge in unstable patients
Rupture can be prevented with antibiotics alone - surgical repair is essential

common_organisms.salmonella: Most common in elderly, especially Salmonella enteritidis, typhimurium
common_organisms.staphylococcus_aureus: Common with IV drug use, endocarditis

definitions_glossary.mycotic_aneurysm: Infected arterial aneurysm caused by bacterial seeding (despite the fungal-sounding name)
definitions_glossary.saccular_aneurysm: Asymmetric, focal outpouching affecting only part of the arterial circumference
definitions_glossary.septic_embolus: Infected clot that travels through bloodstream and lodges in arterial wall

antibiotics.duration: Minimum 6 weeks IV, often lifelong oral suppression

open_repair.in_situ_reconstruction: With rifampin-soaked Dacron or cryopreserved allograft
open_repair.extra_anatomic_bypass: Axillobifemoral with aortic ligation if severe contamination

endovascular.role: Bridge therapy in hemodynamically unstable patients
endovascular.concerns: Placing graft in infected field, requires prolonged antibiotics
endovascular.outcomes: Acceptable short-term, higher late infection rate

prognosis.late_infection: Risk of graft infection, especially with in situ prosthetic repair

definition.@value: Infected arterial aneurysm caused by bacterial seeding of the arterial wall

learning_objectives: Recognize clinical and imaging features of mycotic aneurysm
Plan surgical approach for infected aneurysm
clinical_pearls: Salmonella + elderly patient + GI symptoms = high suspicion for mycotic aneurysm
Blood cultures are positive in only 50-75% - negative cultures do not exclude diagnosis
Saccular, rapidly enlarging, atypical location = think infected
Cryopreserved allograft may have lower reinfection rate than prosthetic
